title: Introduction

body:
The Page not found error (404 HTTP status code) is one of the most common issues that visitors meet when browsing the websites. 

MVC applications typically execute user actions. Even when a user performs a request which the application doesn't support, it's unacceptable for any professional application to return a user-unfriendly error message, such as an HTTP status code or even worse, the YSOD (Yellow-Screen-Of-Death which IIS returns by default).

The status code is too technical for website visitors, and they won't understand what's happening and what they should do differently. On the other hand, the YSOD contains parts of your code which can expose a potential vulnerability - and introduce a security issue. That's why a user-friendly error page is a must.

Errors in MVC websites

In general, there are two types of errors in ASP.NET MVC websites, and they are raised either by the MVC application itself or by the IIS.

The following errors are typically raised by an MVC application:

  • The URL requested by the user doesn't match any route on the website.
  • The URL matches a route, but a specific controller or controller action isn't found.
  • Controller action returns System.Web.Mvc.HttpNotFoundResult by, e.g., calling the HttpNotFound method.

The IIS can raise the following errors:

  • File the user requested doesn't exist.
  • There is no binding for the requested extension, e.g, jpg1.
  • Static file handler doesn't find the file on the disc.

Handling the 404 error

Any suitable response to a 404 error in a modern MVC application should ensure the following:

  • It preserves the original request URL.
  • It doesn't respond with a 302 redirect.
  • It returns correct 404 HTTP status code.

Implementing the error page

In the ASP.NET framework, there is a number of approaches you can take to implement how your website deals with error pages.

We recommend handling errors on the IIS level by creating a custom friendly error MVC page or a static .html page and specify the path to the error page in the application's Web.config using the httpErrors element.

Regarding the content of the error page, you can implement any of the following scenarios:

  • Create a static .html page with a hard-coded content to display as an error message.
  • Create a general MVC page which contains user-friendly error message hard-coded in the view's markup (for details see how we developed the Medio Clinic's error page).
  • Give a full control over the content of the error page to editors. You can create a NotFound page type with a suitable URL pattern and provide editors with means, e.g., suitable form controls, to populate the page with content they want to link or promote to their customers. The editors will then use the page type and create a Not found error page in the content tree. (Using this approach, you'll also need to implement the features to retrieve the content of the page to the live site. The implemented custom error page will be just another item in the content tree, and you can follow the same steps you took to display, e.g., the Home and other pages on the Medio Clinic live site.)

Setting IIS to handle 404 HTTP exceptions

If you decide to use any of the three approaches, you need to configure the behavior of your application when an error occurs. The following snippet sets that the IIS handles 404 HTTP errors.

protected void Application_Error()
{
    // Sets 404 HTTP exceptions to be handled via IIS (behavior is specified in the "httpErrors" section in the Web.config file)
    var error = Server.GetLastError();
    if ((error as HttpException)?.GetHttpCode() == 404)
    {
        Server.ClearError();
        Response.StatusCode = 404;
    }
}

Creating a static HTML error page

Having a static .html page is arguably the safest possible approach. In some cases, it can be easier to develop, but it requires that you hard-code the styling of the page to match your website's layout and provide the user with a consistent experience.

On the other hand, if there is any change to the basic site's layout, such as if there are new items in the websites' navigation, you need to update also the code of your static error page to match the experience which brings unnecessary expenses.

The following code snippet shows how to reference your error page in the Web.config's system.WebServer node.

<system.webServer>
    ...
    <httpErrors errorMode="Custom" existingResponse="Auto">
        <remove statusCode="404" subStatusCode="-1" />
        <error statusCode="404" path="HttpErrors\404.html" responseMode="File"/>
    </httpErrors>
    ...
</system.webServer>

Creating a custom MVC error page

To use all MVC features, such as already defined website's layout or dynamically resolved navigation menu, you can create a custom NotFound controller with actions that handle the errors you need and return suitable views. Again, you need to reference the path to the respective controller action in the Web.config. You can see this approach in use on the Medio Clinic website.
title: 404 error pages in Kentico MVC

body:
Medio Clinic uses a custom user-friendly error MVC page.

The site's Global.asax sets that the errors are handled by the IIS. The behavior is specified in the site's web.config which defines handling error by an <httpErrors> element added to the Web.config's web.webServer section.

The "/notfound"  path's attribute of the <error> element matches the NotFound route in the RouteConfig.cs class. The route invokes the NotFoundController's Index action. title: Introduction

body:
The performance of a website built with Kentico MVC development model depends on many factors. Besides the number of pages or the quality of code, there are factors related to hardware and environment on which both applications and the shared database are running or the available resources if the server is shared with other applications. It's better to optimize the application before it's deployed live - and runs into number of issues.

The following list gives you some ideas about what to consider when you build a website in Kentico MVC development model - or when your live application runs into any performance issues.

_items.body:
Website editors can store content in content-only pages, custom tables, or media libraries. Each storage option is designed for a different type of data.

Find out as much as you can about the client's business requirements so you can organize the content the best possible way. You have already learned about their limitations, however, if you get stuck with defining the optimal website content structure, feel free to refresh your knowledge in Kentico documentation or gain more insights in the Planning Your Site Data Structure article.
_items.title: Organize website content in the most effective way

_items.body:
The performance problems are often caused by small things which grow into massive issues.

Besides not using caching (see more about caching later), many of the performance issues are caused by inefficient SQL queries.

One of the most common issues with slow SQL queries comes from cascading the SQL queries into a series of subsequent calls to SQL server.

For example, when retrieving data for menus, developers tend to get the menu items in the first SQL query. Then they run a second query to return data for their second-level menu items. And to complement data from the second query, they add a third query. As a result, the number of queries grows exponentially - and the database suddenly struggles to answer 1000+ requests. 

Instead of flooding the database with short queries, try joining multiple queries to get data at once into one efficient. The performance of your website will improve.

Another performance issue is caused by developers who don’t limit the amount of data they get from the database. Specify the source of the data with hard-coded values, limit the number of rows you retrieve with by calling the TopN method.

Finding sources of issues

Check the system log

The Event log application logs information about all the events that occur in the Kentico admin interface and the MVC application. You can use the information to identify an unwanted behavior that occurred in the system and get insights to where the problem originated or give you additional details.

Use debugging tools in Kentico and the MVC application

To debug your SQL queries requested from the live site MVC application, you can use the open-source Glimpse diagnostic tool. To use Glimpse on Kentico website, you need to install the related NuGet packages (Kentico.Glimpse and Glimpse.Mvc5) and turn Glimpse on. To see information on Glimpse's Kentico SQL tab, you need to Enable SQL query debug in the Kentico Settings application.

Find out more about using Glimpse to debug SQL queries in our documentation. If you are new to Glimpse, you might find Kentico MVC Brian McKeiver's article Why Kentico.Glimpse is a Must Have Tool for Kentico MVC Developers - or you can check official Microsoft MVC documentation.

SQL Server Profiler is another option you can use to see a number of executed queries, what the queries looked like, how much time it took to execute the queries - and what other queries were called within the context of the request. However, to get the optimal information, you'd have to filter system queries ran by Kentico API.
_items.title: Check your code in the MVC application

_items.body:
Loading files from the database is a demanding operation. If your site stores a large number of files, we recommend storing the files in the file system. 

To improve loading time for files stored in the media libraries, use the DirectUrl property. However, if the project's business requirements demand that the system needs to check permissions before it displays the file to the user, you need to use PermanentUrl property to get the file's URL.
_items.title: Configure the file storage

_items.body: Scheduled tasks run on Kentico back-end, and you can use the Scheduled tasks application to configure how to the system executes automatic tasks. If you run both the administration interface and the MVC application in one service, you can slightly improve the website's performance by disabling all unnecessary tasks or increasing their execution interval.
_items.title: Limit scheduled tasks

_items.body:
Caching allows you to store previously requested data in the memory and serve a copy of this data to other users' requests. When set correctly, caching can significantly improve the performance of your website.

Cached data load more quickly because the memory which stores the cache tends to be faster than other storage spaces, such as database or file system. Similarly, caching data reduces the number of page processing operations, such as retrieving data from the database or performing calculations.

Cache keys

Kentico built-in caching mechanism works primarily on the server side. The system saves cache items into the cache in the form of cache keys.

Cache keys have unique names which exactly identify the cached content. Each key stores the cached data and other information, such as the expiration time or dependencies.

Cache dependencies

By default, the cache is saved for the set interval. The system flushes the cache when the given interval expires.

In Kentico, you can set relationships between the cached objects which you can use to override the default system behavior.  Cache dependencies allow your application to automatically clear cached data when related objects in the admin interface or the MVC application are modified. 

To create dependencies between objects, Kentico uses dummy cache keys. The dummy keys are cache object items without any data. They serve to establish relationships between objects (or group of objects). When an object is modified, the system "touches" the corresponding dummy keys. As a result, the system clears any cache which is defined as related to modified objects.

For example, your MVC website lists news articles on the website. The dummy key "nodes|MySite|ArticleProvider|all" is touched any time editors add, update or delete any of the site's articles. The example uses minimal cache dependencies, see you can configure much complex cache dependencies in Kentico documentation.

Find out more on how to improve the performance of the MVC site using data caching and caching controller actions below.
_items.title: Configure caching

_items.body: If there are longer periods of inactivity on your website, your users may experience longer delays when they first open the site. Consider setting up the Idle time-out property of your IIS application pool to higher values.
_items.title: Increase the application pool Idle Time-out

_items.body: When the performance of your website is still unsatisfactory after you have taken every possible step, consider upgrading the hosting environment. You can either scale out and add more servers that will host the same content into your web farm, or scale up and upgrade your hardware.

title: Optimizing website performance

body:
The admin UI and the MVC live site MVC application run in a web farm which syncs cache between the instances. The web farm ensures that the MVC application invalidates cache according to the content or setting changes made in the application and vice versa.

To improve the performance of your website, we recommend that you cache data retrieved from the shared database as well as the output of the controller actions in your MVC application.

Caching data in MVC applications

We recommend you to cache data queried from the database,  namely if the data is frequently accessed. For example, you may want to cache data for individual pages, forms, and any other data stored in Kentico database.

There are many approaches you can take to handle caching.

For example, you can cache data in individual repositories that use the providers you generated for your content-only pages. To cache data in your code, you can use the CacheHelper.Cache method and make use of cache dependencies.

We recommend you to always generate cache keys with names that include all the parameters you used to retrieve the data from the database to ensure consistent browsing experience. 

For example, when the visitor switches to a new culture, you don't want them to see cached articles in the old culture. To prevent the inconsistency, you can include a culture code variable in the cache key for the page data.

using System;
using System.Linq;

using CMS.Helpers;
using CMS.SiteProvider;

(...)

public Article GetArticle(int nodeGUID)
{
    // Defines site culture and site name
    string culture = "en-us";
    string siteName = SiteContext.CurrentSiteName;
    
    // Loads the data for the article in the specified culture on the specified site
    Func<Article> dataLoadMethod = () => ArticleProvider.GetArticle(nodeGUID, culture, siteName)
                                                        .TopN(1)
                                                        .FirstOrDefault();
    // Creates a new instance of CacheSettings object with the 10-minute expiry limit for the given article
    var cacheSettings = new CacheSettings(10, "mysite|data|article", nodeGUID, culture, siteName)
    {
        GetCacheDependency = () =>
        {
            // Creates cache dependencies. The cache clears the data when any culture version of the specified article is modified in Kentico
            string dependencyCacheKey = String.Format("nodeGUID|{0}", nodeGUID);
            return CacheHelper.GetCacheDependency(dependencyCacheKey);
        }
    };

    return CacheHelper.Cache(dataLoadMethod, cacheSettings);
}

To name another approach, you can abstract from the generated classes in Kentico a create service to handle caching separately. You can see this approach used in the Medio Clinic training website which is described below.

Finally, you can introduce an even much higher level of abstraction, and using the AOP pattern decorate individual repositories with code that caches results of specified methods. You can see this approach used in our sample DancingGoatMVC website.

Caching controller action output in MVC applications

You can cache the output of individual controller actions using the standard ASP.NET output caching. Output caching can significantly increase your website performance, especially if you cache the output of all possible controller actions, such as returned views that are frequently requested.

Use the OutputCache attribute to mark the action methods or the controller's outputs you want to cache. The OutputCache attribute allows you to set cache duration in seconds and adjust some additional properties.

When storing the output cache on the server (the OutputCache attribute's Location property is set to Server), you can define cache dependencies to tailor your implementation to fit various scenarios that use both static and dynamic content. You can add the dependencies in individual action methods using the HttpContext.Response.AddCacheItemDependency() method. Because controller actions can be called in situations in which the dummy cache items have not yet been created, ensure that the dummy cache items exist by calling CacheHelper.EnsureDummyKey().

In the following snippet, you can see an implementation of OutputCache attribute that makes use of Kentico dummy cache key items. (The cache is flushed when any of the articles the method works with is modified, deleted or a new article is created. You can find more information on how to configure cache dependencies for your scenarios in Kentico documentation.)

using System;
using System.Web.UI;
using System.Web.Mvc;

using CMS.Helpers;
(...)

// Sets the output cache to 600 seconds for all items and stores the cached data on server
[OutputCache(Duration=600, VaryByParam="none", Location = OutputCacheLocation.Server)]
public ActionResult Index()
{
    var articles = mArticleRepository.GetArticles();

    // Sets cache dependencies. The system clears the cache when any article is modified in Kentico.
    string dependencyCacheKey = String.Format("nodes|mvcsite|{0}|all", Article.ClassName.ToLowerInvariant());

    // Ensures that the dummy key exists
    CacheHelper.EnsureDummyKey(dependencyCacheKey);

   // Adds the cache dependency key 
    HttpContext.Response.AddCacheItemDependency(dependencyCacheKey);

    return View(articles);
}

Many modern websites achieve their stunning design and smooth behavior by applying advanced CSS styles and running many scripts. The design-related instructions are stored in CSS and JavaScript files which - depending on the complexity of the behavior - can grow into large numbers of files of significant sizes. However, the size and number of resources requested by client browsers directly influence performance when rendering the website's pages.

We recommend that you use bundling and minification in your MVC application which will help improve request load time. 

In short, bundling combines multiple files of the same type, e.g., .css or .js, into a bundle which the client's browser requests as one file. Minification removes white spaces, comments and renames variables to their shortest possible name in text-based files. The process removes all the excess characters which reduces the size of the files and improves their load time while keeping the functionality untouched. Both features are built into the ASP.NET MVC 5 framework and require almost-to-none effort to implement.

You can see a sample implementation of both of the features on the training website. 

The Medio Clinic bundles both the CSS and the JS files. The CSS files are stored in Content/Css/Master folders and they are called on the Layout view by @Styles.Render("~/bundles/master-css") call in the website's header. The scripts are stored in the Scripts/Master folders and called on the shared Layout view using @Scripts.Render("~/bundles/master-scripts") at the end of the HTML markup which is a recommended location for scripts. (For the demo purpose, only the materialize.min.css and materialize.min.js files are minified.) The BundleConfig class defines directories of the resources and is registered in the Medio Clinic's Application_Start method.

When you finish developing and optimizing your MVC website, you will deploy both the admin UI and the MVC application to a production environment.

Deploying the project files

There are several possible ways of deploying the project files from your local environment to the production server. You can use the Visual Studio Publish function, or you can copy the project files directly to the hosting server over FTP.

No matter how you deploy the website, make sure that both applications are correctly configured in the hosting server's IIS. You can find more information about configuring Kentico application in IIS in Kentico documentation. 

Deploying the database

To deploy the database, there are two ways you can take. 

You can restore the database backup on the hosting SQL server (and update the connection strings for both projects in the web.config). Or, you can install a fresh database on your hosting SQL server and use Kentico Export/Import feature to transfer the site. You can find a detailed description of how to transfer the website in Kentico documentation.

To prevent any future issues, you might want to check the Sites application and make sure the domain, presentation URL and any domain aliases are configured correctly for the production domain.

Running MVC website on Microsoft Azure

Both the administration interface and the MVC application can run in Azure. We recommend that you deploy the application to Azure Web Apps using two different Azure App Service hosting plans - one for the MVC application, and another for the administration application.

There are two reasons why we recommend running the MVC site on two services.

  1. Two hosting services are required for the web farm synchronization to run correctly by default. (You can configure the web farm servers' names manually if you decide to run the website in a shared hosting space.)
  2. The two service plans allow you to scale applications independently. In most cases, the MVC live site will receive much higher traffic that the administration interface. Therefore, both sites will have different requirements for performance.

To deploy both the admin interface and the MVC application, you can follow Kentico documentation:

  1. Create an Azure Web App service from Visual Studio
  2. Deploy the project to Azure Web Apps

 Don't forget to configure both applications to the same server time zone.

Kentico staging feature allows you to easily transfer changes made to pages (or other objects) in Kentico instance on one server (e.g., editing) to Kentico instance on another server (e.g., production). Staging is particularly useful when you need to synchronize multiple environments during development, for example: Development -> Testing -> Editing (staging) -> Live (production).

The website built with Kentico MVC development model, every "staged" instance consists of the Kentico administration, the MVC application, and the shared database. For the given example of environments in, e.g., the Editing environment, you will be running an instance of Kentico administration, the MVC application, and the database. Similarly, you will need to have three separate instances for the Live production environment.

You can find detailed information on how to configure the one-directional or bi-directional content staging service for your environment in Kentico documentation.

One-directional vs. bi-directional

While the one-directional services defines exclusive source-target servers, the bi-directional configuration removes the exclusivity of the source server, and allows you to make changes also on the other servers. The changes are then transferred to the rest of the servers.

Staging large files

Kentico allows you to limit the size of files that are synchronized by staging. You can limit the size of pages attachments as well as files stored in the media libraries.

Setting the size limit prevents the system from using too many resources when it synchronizes the large files. The system logs only staging tasks if editors change the files in the Kentico administration interface. If they make changes directly, e.g., using an FTP, Kentico doesn’t log the tasks.

Find out more about limiting the size of the files for staging tasks in Kentico documentation.

Authenticating user in staging

Kentico staging service provides you with two options of authentication - username and password authentication or authentication using X.509 public key certificates. The X.509 is slower and more difficult to configure, but on the other hand, it provides more security compared to the traditional user/password authentication. You can either use the sample private and client certificates in the Kentico application or generate and install your certificates. You can find out more about using the X.509 authentication in Kentico documentation. 

Access permissions in content staging

You can control access to staging actions by configuring user roles permissions within Kentico security model. The permission matrix allows you to grant the following permissions:

  • Manage servers – allows members of the roles to manage target server configurations on the Servers tab in the Staging application.
  • Manage all tasks – allows access to the All tasks tab of the Staging application, and synchronization/management of synchronization tasks.
  • Manage page tasks – allows access to the Pages tab of the Staging application, and synchronization/management of synchronization tasks.
  • Manage object tasks – allows access to the Objects tab of the Staging application, and synchronization/management of synchronization tasks.
  • Manage data tasks – allows access to the Data tab of the Staging application, and synchronization/management of synchronization tasks.
  • Manage task groups – allows members of the roles to create, edit, and delete staging task groups (globally for all sites). The settings affects the Task groups tab of the Staging application and group creation via the dialog in the administration interface header. The Manage task groups permission is NOT required to switch to the context of existing task groups.

The Medio Clinic uses services to separate Kentico code from the MVC application code. You want to cache all the data you retrieve for the top part of the Doctors listing page from the database (the Header property of DoctorSectionDto).

To cache the data from the Doctors page in admin UI (and set the system to invalidate the cache any time the related objects are changed), you can create a service which defines the Cache method.

The CacheService implements ICacheService interface.

The interface defines GetNodesCacheDependencyKey method to get the cache dependency key using two parameters - the class name of the page type and a cache dependency type object with all the object type's values. Implementation of the GetNodesCacheDependencyKey method returns the dependency (dummy cache) key with all the necessary parameters to ensure that the website provides consistent experience - its name, site name, the object type, and its values.

For caching data, the ICacheService interface defines the Cache method. The implementation of the method in the CacheService class wraps CacheHelper.Cache method in Kentico API. In one call, the custom method returns the cacheSettings with the passed parameters (the type of the cached data, duration of the cache and the cache item name) and the dependency key item.

Call the custom CacheService.Cache method on the DoctorsController's Index action to retrieve the data (if there isn't any already cached) into the DoctorSectionDto, cache it for 60 minutes, name the cache item, and set cache dependency key.

You want to cache the results of the DoctorsController Details action - the individual Doctor pages - in the server memory for 60 minutes.  At the same time, you also want to flush the cache if editors modify the page in the content tree.

  1. To set up the relationships, define and implement GetNodeCacheDependencyKey method which returns the cache key with parameters like the site name or the nodeGUID of the given page. 
  2. Implement SetNodeCacheDependencyKey method which accepts as a parameter the nodeGUID of the page in the content tree. To ensure the system stability, have the method first verify that there is an item in the cache which matches the parameter, and then set the dependency on the current HttpContext.

The implemented feature now flushes the cache whenever there is a change to an item in the content tree that matches the values specified in the dependency key.

Decorate the DoctorsController Detail action with the OutputCache attribute.

  1. Set the output cache duration to 3600 seconds, make nodeGuid the defining parameter, and store the cached output on the server.
  2. To set the dependency on the cache item, call the CacheService.SetOutputCacheDependency() method with the nodeGuid as the method's parameter.

The implemented feature now stores the controller output until the cache expires or until editors modify the doctor object.
